contents: Proponents of the “information age,” as the current era is often known, argue that people today (22) <u>read and are writing</u> more than ever. They claim that we are constantly composing and receiving text messages, tweeting, posting on social media, and researching information online. (23) <u>They proudly assert that more people read and write today, than at any other time in human history, and do so more frequently,</u> Critics accept this argument, but with this caveat: while people may be consuming more information than ever before, they may be doing less critical thinking about what they consume. (24a) <u>People are also less likely to memorize their friends’ phone numbers.</u> (24b) <u>In other words, the increase in quantity brings about a decrease in quality.</u>
